awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Enhanced Nonradiative Energy Coupling between Quantum Dot Phosphors and InGaN Emitters - Towards High-Efficiency White LEDs
awd_abstract_narration:
Objective: 
This project aims to explore the application of colloidal compound quantum dots (QDs) for the development of high-efficiency white light emitting diodes (LEDs) for solid state lighting. The conventional, multistep, absorption-¬reemission color-conversion scheme in phosphor-based white LEDs will be replaced by non-resonant cavity-enhanced direct energy coupling between colloidal CdSe/(Cd,Zn)S QD-phosphors and electrically-pumped InGaN quantum wells/dots. The goal of this work will be to design and fabricate a new generation of white light sources featuring significantly improved radiation efficiency, high brightness and high color rendering index as well as low manufacturing costs. 

Intellectual Merit: 
This project offers a synergistic approach to advance the science and technology of nonradiative energy transfer between epitaxially-grown quantum structures with chemically-synthesized colloidal nanocrystal quantum dots. In addition, it provides a platform whereupon emerging QD technologies, including QD-assembled microcavities, engineered core-shell QDs, and mist-patterning of multicolor QDs, will be integrated for the first time for the implementation of a functional photonic system.   

Broader Impacts: 
The results from this project will find application in next-generation white light sources that will provide great energy savings. Participation by industrial investigators will facilitate the integration of results from this project into commercial products. The project will offer focused research and learning experiences to the graduate and undergraduate student participants, and findings will be integrated into classroom instruction, providing opportunities for students to connect fundamental nanoscience to real-world applications of nanotechnology. New activities will also be created for high school campers.

por.por_cntn:
The potential uses of colloidal quantum dot (QD) phosphors with group III nitride white light emitting diodes (LEDs) have grown due to the recent discovery of a path for indirect injection of electron-hole pairs into QDs by nonradiative energy transfer from the InGaN/GaN quantum wells (QWs) that are in close proximity to the QDs. This nonradiative energy transfer can potentially enhance the efficiency of the color conversion process because it removes several intermediate steps involved in the conventional multi-step down conversion scheme.

As promising as the QD-based white LEDs are, a serious drawback of the present colloidal QD technology is its dependence on heavy-metal cations, such as cadmium, lead, and mercury. We conducted studies to synthesize non-toxic and environmentally safe heavy-metal-free colloidal QDs. We designed an improved preparation method to synthesize heavy-metal-free CuInS2-ZnS QDs (ZCIS) with high quantum yields. Bright and organic-free electroluminescence (EL) that peaked at red, yellow, and green wavelengths was achieved from the ZCIS QD-LEDs. The recorded maximum brightness ranged from 1200-1600 cd/m2.

The emission efficiency of colloidal QDs is one of the key parameters influencing the color-conversion efficiency in QD-based white LEDs. We conducted accurate measurements of the emission efficiency of colloidal QDs. A rapid rise in efficiency was observed upon the transition from spontaneous to stimulated emission in the QDs, with a maximum value of 34% achieved. Theoretical studies were performed to model the excitation density-dependent emission efficiency of the QDs. The newly recognized efficiency of the QD emission can be utilized to the design of QD emitters in QD-based white LED technology.

In QD-based white light LEDs, multicolor QDs are required to couple with the InGaN LEDs for the output of white light. In order to minimize the re-absorption losses associated with multicolor QDs, there will also be a need to selectively pattern yellow/green and red QDs over the InGaN emissive layer such that QDs of different spectral emission are not mixed. We built upon a mist-deposition process developed at Penn State for the assembly and patterning of colloidal QDs, allowing tight control over the thickness, surface morphology, and composition of the emissive QD layers. The results suggest that the scalable technology of mist-deposition can be used to selectively assemble multicolor QDs in white LED fabrication.

While the QD-based white LEDs hold great potential for solid-state lighting, the fabrication of such devices cannot be accomplished with traditional nitride LED configurations. In designing QD-QW coupled white LEDs, it is essential to keep the QDs in the immediate vicinity of the QW surface. This requirement is in conflict with the fact that a doped GaN contact layer needs to cap the InGaN QW to complete the p-i-n LED structure. We designed a novel nanopillar LED structure to address the conflict. The nanopillar LEDs were fabricated by using an improved method using an inductively-coupled-plasma etch, which utilized self-assembled In3Sn nanodots as the etch mask. Efficient sidewall coupling between QDs and QWs was rendered by depositing QDs into the gaps between the nanopillars. Strong non-radiative energy transfer was observed from the InGaN multiple quantum well (MQW) to the colloidal QD phosphors, which led to a 263% enhancement in effective internal quantum efficiency for the QDs incorporated in nanopillar LEDs in comparison with those deposited over planar LED structures. This work represents an important step in the development of high-efficiency white LEDs based on QD-coupled nanostructured InGaN emitters.
